channel.title: News Medical Parkinsons Disease News Feed
channel.description: Latest Parkinsons Disease News and Research

item.title: Brain stimulation combined with nasal spray containing nanoparticles can improve stroke recovery
item.description: In a recent study, researchers from Xi'an Jiaotong-Liverpool University and other universities in China have reported that brain stimulation combined with a nose spray containing nanoparticles can improve recovery after ischemic stroke in an animal model.

media:content.media:description: Brain stimulation combined with nasal spray containing nanoparticles can improve stroke recovery

item.title: Study explores the role of air pollution on the trajectory of stroke
item.description: Air pollution has been widely associated with an increased risk of stroke. A new study looks at the role of air pollution on the trajectory of stroke, including cardiovascular events after first stroke and death.

media:content.media:description: Study explores the role of air pollution on the trajectory of stroke

item.title: Bariatric surgery recipients may have an elevated risk of epilepsy, study finds
item.description: People who have had bariatric surgery may have an increased risk of developing epilepsy, according to a study published in the September 28, 2022, online issue of Neurology, the medical journal of the American Academy of Neurology.

media:content.media:description: Bariatric surgery recipients may have an elevated risk of epilepsy, study finds

item.title: UW joins the Alliance for Therapies in Neuroscience to transform the fight against neurological diseases
item.description: The University of Washington has joined the Alliance for Therapies in Neuroscience (ATN), a long-term research partnership between academia and industry geared to transform the fight against brain diseases and disorders of the central nervous system.

media:content.media:description: UW joins the Alliance for Therapies in Neuroscience to transform the fight against neurological diseases

item.title: Does leptin play a role in Parkinson’s disease?
item.description: Scientists review in vitro and in vivo evidence associated with Parkinson's disease and leptin.

media:content.media:description: Does leptin play a role in Parkinson’s disease?

item.title: Designing a new treatment to treat migraine effectively
item.description: In this interview, we speak to Mudra Kapoor, Vice President of Global Medical Affairs for Neuroscience at AbbVie, about atogepant, their new treatment option for migraine.

media:content.media:description: Designing a new treatment to treat migraine effectively

item.title: Study reveals the long-term neurologic consequences of COVID-19
item.description: If you've had COVID-19, it may still be messing with your brain. Those who have been infected with the virus are at increased risk of developing a range of neurological conditions in the first year after the infection, new research shows.

media:content.media:description: Study reveals the long-term neurologic consequences of COVID-19

item.title: In-home device can monitor Parkinson's patient's movement and gait speed
item.description: Parkinson's disease is the fastest-growing neurodegenerative disease, now affecting more than 10 million people worldwide, yet clinicians still face huge challenges in tracking its severity and progression.

media:content.media:description: In-home device can monitor Parkinson's patient's movement and gait speed

item.title: SARS-CoV-2 generates amyloid in cerebral spinal fluid
item.description: In a recent study posted to the bioRxiv* preprint server, an international team of researchers demonstrated amyloid aggregation due to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) in human cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

media:content.media:description: SARS-CoV-2 generates amyloid in cerebral spinal fluid

item.title: Discovery could resolve one of the mysteries of Parkinson's disease
item.description: Aggregates of the protein alpha-synuclein spread in the brains of people with Parkinson's disease through a cellular waste-ejection process, suggests a new study led by Weill Cornell Medicine researchers.

media:content.media:description: Discovery could resolve one of the mysteries of Parkinson's disease
